helpInfo:
As machine knitters, it's important that the yarn is "put up" so it can easily pass through the yarn tensioner for knitting.

Yarn that is put up in skeins and hanks cannot be used for machine knitting unless it is wound on a cone or in balls (or cakes).

Many machine knitters will also re-wind yarn into balls and check for knots before using it for machine knitting.

example: Depending on the construction and fiber, some yarns will bias when knit. No amount of blocking will remove the bias.
imageAlt: Bias in machine knitting and techniques to reduce it
imageDescription: Bias in machine knitting caused by certain yarns, with solutions to reduce it
helpInfo:
Bias in machine knitting refers to the tendency of some yarns to skew or stretch diagonally. This is a natural characteristic of certain yarns and can’t always be corrected by blocking.

Here are some tips to try to overcome bias
  • Carry a matching sewing thread
  • Try Plaiting
  • Use a stitch pattern
  • Knit a knit and purl pattern with your ribber
  • Knit looser
  • Use the yarn for Knitweave
  • Stripe with another (not-biasing) yarn
  • Use the yarn for hand knitting or crochet
metaTitle: Bias: Definition in Machine Knitting
metaDescription: Bias in machine knitting refers to yarns that tend to skew or stretch diagonally. Solutions include specific stitch patterns and combining yarns to reduce bias.

example: A textured yarn created in the spinning process.
imageAlt: Bouclé textured yarn used in machine knitting

helpInfo:
Bouclé is a style of yarn that is textured in the spinning process. Multiply plies of yarn are spun where one of the plies is held more loosely as the yarn is spun, forming loops or gimps. The yarn is often held together with a "binder".

Because the yarn is textured, even plain knitting can be interesting. Mixing a smooth yarn and a bouclé can produce beautiful results.

example: A knitting machine brand name.  Often these were the same machine, just packaged under a different name in different parts of the world.
imageAlt: Brother | Knit King knitting machines brands
imageDescription: Brother and Knit King knitting machines with pre-select needle patterning
helpInfo:
The Brother/Knit King machines are unique when compared to Silver/Singer/Studio machines (again same machines, different brand packaging)

In addition to different terminology, the positioning of buttons/levers/dials, and other differences, in general, the biggest difference between the 2 brands is in the automatic patterning (punchcard or electronics).

Brother/Knit King
When working in pattern, the Brother/Knit King machines pre-select needles in preparation for the patterning to happen on the following row.

For example:
Row 1: Knit the row and pre-select the needles
Row 2: Knit the row in pattern according to the currently selected needles AND pre-select for the next row.

Silver/Singer/Studio
When working in pattern, the Silver/Singer/Studio machines select the needles AND knit all in one pass of the carriage.

For example:
Row 1: Knit the row and "memorize" the pattern for the next row
Row 2: Knit the row according to the memorized instructions AND memorize the pattern for the next row.

There are other differences in the machines, but these basic needle selection schemes can trip up knitters who work with both brands.

Is one brand "better" than another? It depends on who you ask Most knitters have a preference and it often depends on which brand they started knitting with.
metaTitle: Brother | Knit King Knitting Machines: Definition
metaDescription: Brother and Knit King are knitting machine brands with pre-select needle functions for patterns, distinct from Silver/Singer/Studio machines

example: A device to hold the carriage in position when transporting the machine

imageAlt: Knitting machine with carriage positioned on the left side
imageDescription: Photograph of a knitting machine showcasing the carriage placed on the left, illustrating its setup for specific knitting techniques.
helpInfo:
For clarity when working specific techniques, pattern instructions may indicate the position of the carriage.

Commonly:
When the carriage is on the right, the row counter should indicate an even number.
When the carriage is on the left, the row counter should indicate an odd number.

Generally you start knitting with the carriage on the right and the row counter set to 000.

Is this a hard-and-fast rule? No... but this convention will help you keep track as you knit.

helpInfo:
Vintage patterns will indicate that knitting machine's carriage is positioned on the left side of the needle bed, ready to move across the needles to knit the next row.

For clarity when working specific techniques, pattern instructions may indicate the position of the carriage.

Commonly:

When the carriage is on the right, the row counter should indicate an even number.
When the carriage is on the left, the row counter should indicate an odd number.

Generally you start knitting with the carriage on the right and the row counter set to 000.

Is this a hard-and-fast rule? No... but this convention will help you keep track as you knit.

metaTitle: Decrease Techniques in Machine Knitting - Knit It Now Glossary
metaDescription: Learn about decrease techniques in machine knitting with Knit It Now's comprehensive glossary. Enhance your knitting skills with clear definitions and expert guidance.

helpInfo:
There are times when you are instructed to increase or decrease evenly across a row. This instruction could be used for creating gathers or reducing a large number of stitches in work.

Unlike in hand knitting, machine knitters need to remove the knitting from the machine, then rehang the stitches accordingly.
Stitches can be removed with a garter bar, waste knitting or a hand knitting needle.

  • Increasing: After removing the stitches from the machine, pull out the desired number of needles and rehang the stitches, skipping needles. Fill in the empty needles with the purl strand from the row below, or leave the needles empty for eyelets, increasing the number of stitches in work.

  • Decreasing: After removing the stitches from the machine, pull out the desired number of needles and rehang the stitches, doubling up stitches on needles evenly across the row, reducing the number of stitches in work.

example: As we machine knit, the knitting is stretched across the needlebed and we add weights. Dressing a swatch will give you a much more accurate gauge measurement and it will also account for any changes when you steam and/or wash your knitting.
helpInfo:
Dressing a swatch refers to the process of establishing the final condition of the knitting after resting, steaming and/or washing.
Knitting straight off the machine is not representative of how the knitting is going to feel, look, drape or measure in the finished garment. Dressing a swatch:
  1. Remove the knitting from the machine
  2. Tube the knitting (roll it lengthwise and pull to "pop" the stitches)
  3. Let it rest (at least overnight)
  4. Wash and/or steam the swatch as you are going to treat the final garment
  5. Measure and calculate your gauge
Once you've dressed the swatch you will know if the yarn shrinks, stretches, fades or biases. You'll be able to confidently knit your garment without any surprises.

Classroom:
Swatching is NOT Optional

Unlike in hand knitting, machine knitters need to remove the knitting from the machine, then rehang the stitches accordingly.
Stitches can be removed with a garter bar, waste knitting or a hand knitting needle.

  • Increasing: After removing the stitches from the machine, pull out the desired number of needles and rehang the stitches, skipping needles. Fill in the empty needles with the purl strand from the row below, or leave the needles empty for eyelets, increasing the number of stitches in work.

  • Decreasing: After removing the stitches from the machine, pull out the desired number of needles and rehang the stitches, doubling up stitches on needles evenly across the row, reducing the number of stitches in work.

example: To help keep bands from "popping out" and laying flat against the body, it's common practice to "grade" the tension as you knit the band piece(s).
imageAlt: Grade the tension in machine knitting
imageDescription: Grading the tension to shape and fit machine knit fabrics with smooth transitions
helpInfo:
Grading tension (for bands)
For example:
  1. Pick up and hang the neckline edge
  2. Start knitting the band at the band tension
  3. Gradually REDUCE the carriage tension (make smaller) and knit to the turning row
  4. Knit the turning row
  5. Gradually INCREASE the tension (make larger) until you are back to the band tension

helpInfo:
Hung hems are a staple for machine knitters (especially for standard gauge machines) and they are a basis for many designer techniques.

They are a great alternative to ribbing.

  • Cast on and knit the depth of the hem
  • Knit a turning row
  • Knit the depth of the hem again
  • Re-hang the cast on edge to form the hem
  • Continue knitting

helpInfo:
There are times when you are instructed to increase or decrease evenly across a row. This instruction could be used for creating gathers or reducing a large number of stitches in work.

Unlike in hand knitting, machine knitters need to remove the knitting from the machine, then rehang the stitches accordingly.
Stitches can be removed with a garter bar, waste knitting or a hand knitting needle.

  • Increasing: After removing the stitches from the machine, pull out the desired number of needles and rehang the stitches, skipping needles. Fill in the empty needles with the purl strand from the row below, or leave the needles empty for eyelets, increasing the number of stitches in work.

  • Decreasing: After removing the stitches from the machine, pull out the desired number of needles and rehang the stitches, doubling up stitches on needles evenly across the row, reducing the number of stitches in work.

example: A technique that allows color changes in the middle of the row without having floats across the back of the knitting.
helpInfo:
Intarsia can be worked in different ways:
  • Manual:
    Using slip or hold, each color is worked with a single pass of the carriage. It will take multiple passes of the carriage to knit multiple colors across the row.
  • Built-in Intarsia Setting:
    Some machines can knit intarsia in one pass of the carriage with a carriage setting. Lay strands of yarn across the needles to be knit and pass the carriage, knitting multiple colors across the row.
  • Intarsia Carriage:
    Some machines offer an intarsia carriage accessory. This replaces the knitting carriage. Lay strands of yarn across the needles to be knit and pass the carriage, knitting multiple colors across the row.
No matter what method is used, it it important to twist the yarns where they join to prevent holes.

imageAlt: Animated demonstration of Knit-wrap-Knit in machine knitting
imageDescription: Animated demonstration of the Knit-wrap-Knit method in machine knitting
helpInfo:
When working short rows or partial knitting (manual wrap method). The knitting sequence to prevent holes:
  • Opposite the carriage place needles in hold (carriage set to hold)
  • Knit across the row
  • Wrap the first needle in hold to prevent a hole
  • Knit back to complete the short row shaping (2 rows knit)


An alternative to manual wrap is to Automatic Wrap.

imageAlt: Lace carriage component in machine knitting
imageDescription: Detailed view of a lace carriage used in machine knitting operations
helpInfo:
Different models have different approaches to lace carriages:



Brother Lace Carriage
Brother lace carriage is used alternately with the main knitting carriage. Based on instruction from the patterning device (electronic or punchcard), the lace carriage selects and transfers stitches. The main carriage is then used to knit the row
Singer/Silver Lace Carriage
Silver/Singer lace carriages work independently of the main knitting carriage. The lace carriage, selects, transfers and knits the row.

helpInfo:
The term "linker" refers to 2 different devices
  • An optional carriage that is manually cranked across the needlebed that pulls stitch-through-stitch as if binding off with a latch tool.
    The final row of the knitting is worked very LOOSELY and the linker then binds off each stitch. Brother and Silver Brands offered ths device. They are no longer being made.

    Silver/Singer SC-3
  • Another device is a Hague Linker. This is a larger device that is separate from the knitting machine. It allows you join the seams of your knitting. There are manual and electric models available. These devices are still being made

example: Mathematical equation for charting stitches and rows. Diophantine Equation
helpInfo:
In charting knitting patterns, we use this equation for numerous applications.
  • Straight line decreasing and increasing of side seams on skirts, sleeves, slacks, and jackets
  • Multiple increasing or decreasing across a single row of knitting.
  • Placing darts and buttonholes
  • Arranging short row increments for curves
  • Determining the stitches in knitting a slanted line
  • One can determine rows and/or stitches to be increased or decreased WITHIN a definite amount of space.
  • Buttonhole placement, vertical or horizontal, can be situated in exactly balanced spots
  • Short row operations can be determined for shoulder slants, pockets, collars, and all kinds of sideways knitting.

example: Keep track of the needles in work by marking the needlebed instead of recording needle numbers
imageAlt: Knitting machine needle bed with marked needles
imageDescription: Marked Needlebed for Stitch Pattern Guidance in Machine Knitting
helpInfo:
If you've removed your knitting and need to rehang it on the same needles, it's often easier to mark the needlebed instead of recording the needle numbers.

Use a soft pencil or a water based marker.
It will be immediately obvious what needles to use.

This can also be used when hand manipulating stitches. For example, mark the needles used for cables instead of counting.

example: Mixing 2 colors of yarn for a mottled or streaked appearance
imageAlt: Marled yarn technique in machine knitting
imageDescription: Marled technique in machine knitting using two contrasting yarns
helpInfo:
2 Yarn ends for marled fabric

Machine knitters, get creative with yarn and color!
  • Run 2 strands of contrasting (or complementary) colors together. The yarn will “automatically” create interesting stripes for a graphic design
  • Stack cones and run the lower end through the top cone, allowing the yarns to twist as they are fed in to your yarn feeder
  • Use a yarn twister and the stripes disappear and you get a marled fabric
This sample is full needle rib (all needles in work on both beds) in the beautiful Jaggerspun Superfine Merino.

What’s a yarn twister?
A yarn twister is a nifty device that looks similar to a yarn winder. It gives you the ability to twist multiple strands of yarn together.

Lots of options:
Twisting will blend colors and change the texture of the resulting yarn strand. You can twist a fancy or textured yarn with a plain yarn. Make thicker yarn and interesting yarn combinations.

You can find twisters in the used equipment market (often named Darhuma yarn twister) There are also new twisters available from fellow machine knitter, Kris Krafter

example: Main bed carriage component that "reads" and "memorizes" punchcard instructions. (Silver, Singer, Studio)
helpInfo:
This is the heart of automatic patterning on a Silver/Singer/Studio punchcard machine. As the carriage passes the punchcard mechanism, the Memory Drums record the position of the holes in the card. On the return pass of the carriage, the appropriate needles are selected and positioned according to the Cam Setting (stitch technique).

NOTE: Often on machines that have been stored for a long time the memory drums can be locked up. The drum should turn freely for stitch patterning to occur.


NOTE: The memory drum "remembers" previous positioning even if you remove the punchcard. To clear the memory drum memory, remove the punchcard and leave the mechanism engaged. Pass the carriage a few times to reset it, then cancel patterning.

example: The distance between needles in mm
imageAlt: Close-up of knitting machine needle spacing
imageDescription: Visual example of needle pitch on a knitting machine with labeled spacing
helpInfo:
What is needle pitch?
The gauge (pitch) of a knitting machine is determined by the distance between the needles.

If you are a hand knitter, think of the different machine gauges as different hand knitting needle sizes.

NOTE:
Although the machine pitch determines the yarn you can use, the actual stitch sizes (knitting gauge) is controlled with the tension dials on the machine.

In hand knitting terms, think of this as choosing a needle size within a RANGE of needles.

The pitch of your knitting machine determines the range. The tension dials determine the needle size.

Common Terms:
3.6mm Fine Gauge
4.5mm Standard Gauge
5mm Passap
6mm

7mm
Mid-Gauge
9mm Bulky-Gauge

example: Having the knitted piece smaller than the body size for a snug fit
helpInfo:
Ease is the difference between the actual body measurement and the finished garment size
.

Negative ease indicates that the knitted piece is smaller than the body measurement. This is often used for socks and hats that require a snug fit.

Ease is a personal choice. The best way to establish your preferred ease is to measure a knitted item that you like and duplicate those measurements for your finished measurements.

Knit it Now patterns are calculated based on the dimensions you enter. If you enter 40" for the bust and you've included ease, the finished sweater will be 40", including any ease you added. (We do not add additional ease to your measurements)

example: A technique that allows color changes in the middle of the row without having floats across the back of the knitting
helpInfo:
Intarsia can be worked in different ways:
  • Manual:
    Using slip or hold, each color is worked with a single pass of the carriage. It will take multiple passes of the carriage to knit multiple colors across the row.
  • Built-in Intarsia Setting:
    Some machines can knit intarsia in one pass of the carriage with a carriage setting. Lay strands of yarn across the needles to be knit and pass the carriage, knitting multiple colors across the row.
  • Intarsia Carriage:
    Some machines offer an intarsia carriage accessory. This replaces the knitting carriage. Lay strands of yarn across the needles to be knit and pass the carriage, knitting multiple colors across the row.
No matter what method is used, it it important to twist the yarns where they join to prevent holes.

Intarsia

example: The distance between needles in mm
imageAlt: Pitch in machine knitting: needle distance and gauge
imageDescription: Pitch in machine knitting affects yarn compatibility and stitch size, measured in millimeters between needles.
helpInfo:
Do you need yarn on cones for machine knitting?
NO! All you need is to have the yarn wound in a way that will easily feed into the machine.
  • Use a center-pull ball from a yarn manufacturer
  • Rewind skeins or hanks with a ball winder
What weight for your machine?
For success with your knitting machine, you need to make sure you are using a yarn that is the appropriate weight for your machine.

If you are just getting started, use a medium weight yarn that fits in the hooks of the needles. With experience, you can experiment with different weights.

Machines come in different gauges. Gauge (Needle Pitch) refers to the distance between the needles and the size of the hooks of the needles.

Pitch: the distance between the needles (in mm)
What is needle pitch?
The gauge (pitch) of a knitting machine is determined by the distance between the needles.

If you are a hand knitter, think of the different machine gauges as different hand knitting needle sizes.

NOTE:
Although the machine pitch determines the yarn you can use, the actual stitch sizes (knitting gauge) is controlled with the tension dials on the machine.

In hand knitting terms, think of this as choosing a needle size within a RANGE of needles.

The pitch of your knitting machine determines the range. The tension dials determine the needle size.

Common Terms:
3.6mm Fine Gauge
4.5mm Standard Gauge
5mm Passap
6mm
6.5mm
7mm
Mid-Gauge
9mm Bulky-Gauge
metaTitle: Pitch: Definition in Machine Knitting
metaDescription: Pitch is the distance between knitting machine needles, affecting the yarn range and stitch size. Machines vary from fine to bulky gauge, each suited for different yarns.

example: Fibers spun into single strands that are often twisted together to make multiple-ply yarns.
imageAlt: Close-up of multi-ply yarn strands
imageDescription: Example of Ply in Machine Knitting Yarn
helpInfo:
To make yarn, fibers (wool, alpaca, cotton, bamboo etc) are spun into long strands (ply). These strands are then spun (twisted) together to form yarn. Single plys can be very fine (lace weight) to very thick (Islandic Lopi). Various yarns can be made of 2 - 20 plys. These yarns can be referred to as 2-ply, 4 ply, etc.

Using plys to describe yarn weights is still used in some parts of the world, but the meaning isn't always clear. The terms like "4-ply" or "8-ply" are used to describe the weight category of the yarn, not the actual number of strands.

In other parts of the world the terms lace, fingering, DK, worsted, or bulky, are used to describe the yarn's thickness
metaTitle: Ply – Machine Knitting Term
metaDescription: In machine knitting, 'ply' refers to the number of individual strands twisted together to form a single yarn, affecting thickness and strength.

example: Singer/Silver/Studio machines: Point cams determine the range of pattern knitting.
imageAlt: Point cams used to control pattern knitting range
imageDescription: Point cams used in Singer, Silver, and Studio machines to define the range of pattern knitting
helpInfo:
On Singer/Silver/Studio machines, the point cams determine the range of pattern knitting. The devices slide along the back of the needlebed.
Pattern knitting only happens between 2 point cams.

  • When setting Point cams at both edges of the knitting, the pattern will be knitted across the entire row.

  • When knitting isolated motif, position the point cam on each side of where you want the motif to knit, keeping the other sections in plain knitting.

    • Point cams are used in conjunction with the Needle-1 Cam
    Page 19 of the Silver Reed 840 Operation manual
metaTitle: Point Cams: Definition in Machine Knitting
metaDescription: Point cams are used in Singer, Silver, and Studio machines to control pattern knitting, determining the range and placement of motifs across the row.

example: A "mock" lace, knit with one very fine thread/yarn and one thicker yarn.  Adding a very fine thread gives the appearance of lace without stitch transfers.
helpInfo:
Machines with Thread Lace settings:
With the appropriate Cam/Carriage settings, both threads will knit together (as in plaiting), but the fine yarn will knit singly and form "lace holes" with no floats.

This is a great alternative to transferred lace. The sample used a white sewing thread. A more "invisible" choice would be to use a transparent filament, like those used by quilters.

Machines without Thread Lace settings:
The appearance of thread lace can be created using a fine "thread" for the 2nd color of a fairlisle pattern. Unlike machines with a Thread Lace setting, floats will be formed as normal fairisle.

example: Raglan sweaters have no shoulder seam. The sleeve cap expands to the neckline to become the shoulder of the garment.
imageAlt: Raglan sleeve style in machine knitting
imageDescription: Raglan sleeve design with no shoulder seams, offering versatile fit in machine knitting
helpInfo:
This popular sleeve style is a favorite of knitters.

The sleeve/armhole seams are often knit with decorative increases or decreases as a design feature.
An advantage of raglans over other styles is the fit. Because there are no shoulder seams to align with the shoulders they appear to fit a wider range of body types - wide or narrow shoulders.

Many knitters (both hand and machine) enjoy knitting raglan sweaters from the top down.

example: Multiple of 6 rows plus 2
imageAlt: Knitting machine displaying row multiple pattern
imageDescription: Example of Row Multiple in Machine Knitting
helpInfo:
A row multiple is the number of rows needed to complete one vertical repeat of a stitch pattern. It’s how often the pattern repeats as you knit up the fabric.

For example:
A stitch pattern with a row multiple of 4 means the pattern repeats every 4 rows. To keep the design consistent, you’ll work in groups of 4 rows.

Sometimes, patterns include extra rows for balance or symmetry. For instance, if it says "Row multiple of 4 + 2," you’ll repeat the 4-row pattern and then add 2 more rows to finish the design.

Knowing the row multiple is key when planning the height of your project or adding stitch patterns.

Row multiples are use when knitting many stitch patterns including cables.

Course / Classroom:
Cables on the Machine
metaTitle: Row Multiple – Machine Knitting Term
metaDescription: In machine knitting, a row multiple refers to the number of rows that complete a full repeat of a stitch pattern, crucial for aligning designs and shaping garments accurately.

helpInfo:
Allows Interactive Knitting on any non-electronic machine including plastic bed machines even the plastic bed machines like the LK-150, KX-350, KH-400 and passap Vario, etc

Connect the cable to you PC. The other end is velcro'd to the main bed. The magnet (provided) is attached to the carriage. The cable senses the magnet as it passes by on the carriage and forwards the pattern in DesignaKnit by one row.

DAK and Manual (non-patterning) machines

It's common practice to leave a plain stitch along edges that will be seamed.
  1. Plain knitting:
    if you work Mattress Stitch
  2. Shaping:
    It's good practice to work increases and decreases at least 1 stitch from the edge, leaving a seaming stitch
  3. Pattern Knitting:
    Keep a single plain stitch at the edge of your knitting for easier seaming
  4. Ribbing:
    Alternating knit and purl stitches, maintaining the rib stitch pattern makes for a professional finish.

Knitting stitches are not square. With most stitch patterns stitches are wider than they are tall.
When seaming (or picking up) stitches to rows, you will not be joining 1 to 1.

example: Connect a Silver Reed Electronic machine with Designaknit via USB.
imageAlt: SilverLINK 5 knitting machine interface device
imageDescription: SilverLINK 5 Interface for Silver Reed Knitting Machines
helpInfo:
Unlike Brother machines, the Silver machines do not have any internal electronics. The SilverLINK Box translates data from DesignaKnit into a form that the knitting carriage can understand.
The carriage is connected to the SilverLINK box with a Curl Cord (Silver Reed) .

  • Stitch pattern is created in DAK on your computer (equivalent to holes in a punchard)
  • The data from your computer is sent to the SilverLINK box via the USB cable
  • The box "translates" the data into a format the carriage can understand
  • The data is sent to the carriage via the curl cord row by row
  • The data instructs the carriage to select and de-select needles
  • This instruction in combination with the carriage settings (tuck, slip, fairisle, etc) creates stitch patterns in your knitting

This device is used on all 800 series Silver Reed machines. The curl cord is required (older models may not have the curl cord). The SilverLink 5 connects via the curl cord to the main carriage, lace carriage, or the AG50 intarsia carriage. It uses a USB port connection to computers. It can also be used on the Knitmaster/Studio(US) SK550, SK560, and SK580 machines.

Purchase the SilverLINK5 from Knit it Now here

Compare SilverKNIT and SilverLINK

example: A knitting machine brand name.  Often these were the same machine, just packaged under a different name in different parts of the world.
imageAlt: Singer | Silver | Studio knitting machines definition
imageDescription: Singer, Silver, and Studio brand knitting machines
helpInfo:
The Silver/Singer/Studio machines are unique when compared to Brother/Knit King machines (again same machines, different brand packaging)

In addition to different terminology, the positioning of buttons/levers/dials, and other differences, in general, the biggest difference between the 2 brands is in the automatic patterning (punchcard or electronics).

Brother/Knit King
When working in pattern, the Brother/Knit King machines pre-select needles in preparation for the patterning to happen on the following row.

For example:
Row 1: Knit the row and pre-select the needles
Row 2: Knit the row in pattern according to the currently selected needles AND pre-select for the next row.

Silver/Singer/Studio
When working in pattern, the Silver/Singer/Studio machines select the needles AND knit all in one pass of the carriage.

For example:
Row 1: Knit the row and "memorize" the pattern for the next row
Row 2: Knit the row according to the memorized instructions AND memorize the pattern for the next row.

There are other differences in the machines, but these basic needle selection schemes can trip up knitters who work with both brands.

Is one brand "better" than another? It depends on who you ask Most knitters have a preference and it often depends on which brand they started knitting with.
metaTitle: Singer | Silver | Studio Knitting Machines: Definition
metaDescription: Singer, Silver, and Studio are knitting machine brands with unique automatic patterning methods. Differences include needle selection and memorization techniques

example: Japanese flat bed machines are commonly made up of 2 needlebeds facing each other (main bed and ribber). The single or main bed can be used independently.

imageDescription: Single Bed/Main Bed used for stockinette stitch and patterning in machine knitting
helpInfo:
Single/main bed refers to the needlebed with the needles facing the knitter.
  • Plain knitting on the single bed produces stockinette stitch (knit 1 row, purl 1 row).
  • Automatic patterning takes place on the single bed / main bed.

When a ribber is attached, the combination is referred to as "double bed".
Japanese machines have removable ribbers. Passap machines (and others) are "true" double bed machines (the ribber is not removable)

The same process can be used to create Multi-color slip. Needles are missed (slipped) and colors are changed creating colorful, graphic designs.
metaTitle: Slip Stitch – Knitting and Crochet Term
metaDescription: In machine knitting, slip stitch skips stitches to create textures and patterns. In crochet, it joins pieces or moves yarn without adding height.

helpInfo:
• Other than cleaning and oiling your machine, the one essential maintenance item is the spongebar. This bar maintains the needle positions as you knit.
  • No matter how much you use your machine, the sponge will deteriorate over time.
  • A flat spongebar will cause any number of problems and is the first step in troubleshooting knitting problems.
  • A flat spongebar can potentially damage needles and carriage. Do not attempt to even push the carriage back and forth with a flat spongebar.

  • Try out the chosen stitch pattern, maybe it's too tedious... learn this BEFORE starting to knit

Machines with Thread Lace settings:

example: A "mock" lace, knit with one very fine thread/yarn and one thicker yarn.  Adding a very fine thread gives the appearance of lace without stitch transfers.
imageAlt: Machine knitted fabric featuring Thread Lace pattern
imageDescription: Thread Lace (Punch Lace) Pattern in Machine Knitting
helpInfo:
Machines with Thread Lace settings:
With the appropriate Cam/Carriage settings, both threads will knit together (as in plaiting), but the fine yarn will knit singly and form "lace holes" with no floats.

This is a great alternative to transferred lace. The sample used a white sewing thread. A more "invisible" choice would be to use a transparent filament, like those used by quilters.

Machines without Thread Lace settings:
The appearance of thread lace can be created using a fine "thread" for the 2nd color of a fairlisle pattern. Unlike machines with a Thread Lace setting, floats will be formed as normal fairisle.
metaTitle: Thread Lace (Punch Lace) – Machine Knitting Technique
metaDescription: Thread Lace, or Punch Lace, is a machine knitting technique that creates delicate, openwork patterns resembling lace by selectively knitting and tucking stitches.

imageAlt: Yarn being waxed for machine knitting
imageDescription: Applying Wax to Yarn for Smooth Machine Knitting
helpInfo:
Yarn on cones that was wound to be used in a factory is often waxed. This allows for the speed of industrial knitting.

Many machine knitters wax their yarn either as they knit or as they rewind balls/skeins/hangs into cakes. Some knitting machines come with a small bit of wax and ledge on the mast to position it for ease of waxing as you knit.

Waxing yarn is a matter of personal preference.

You may use wax for every knitting project. Some knitters (including me) rarely think about waxing.

  • If you are using old, vintage yarn that has been around for years and is dry and full of static, consider wax.
  • If your machine is not knit knitting well, the yarn is breaking, tangling or stitches are not forming correctly, consider wax.
  • If you are stuggling with static, consider wax.
You don't need anything fancy for wax, just a chunk of paraffin or a white candle works.

Visit our blog to share your opinion about waxing yarn.
metaTitle: Wax – Machine Knitting Accessory
metaDescription: In machine knitting, wax is applied to yarn to reduce friction, ensuring smooth passage through the machine and preventing snags during knitting.

example: Refers to the side of the knitting that will be against the body. Opposed to the Right Side (public side) Often refers to the purl side of stockinette knitting, but it is the choice of the knitter (and the wearer)  (private side)
Repeat this row 2X (2 times)
helpInfo:
Knitting instructions are often abbreviated.

A series of instructions may be repeated multiple times.

Example:
 Row 20: * Transfer every third stitch
Row 21: Knit*
Repeat from * to * 3X

This instruction represents 6 rows
Row 20: Transfer every third stitch
Row 21: Knit
Row 22: Transfer every third stitch
Row 23: Knit
Row 24: Transfer every third stitch
Row 25: Knit
The symbols
*...*
* to *
[...]

are used to highlight the instructions to be repeated

example: A method often used by machine knitters to identify and compare yarn weights
imageAlt: Yards Per Pound (YPP) used to compare yarn weights in machine knitting
imageDescription: Yards Per Pound method for comparing yarn weights and thickness in machine knitting
helpInfo:
A yarn industry standard, using Yards Per Pound, helps compare yarn weights and determine what yarns are best for your knitting machine

No matter what put up (cones, balls skeins) you use being able to compare the weights in YPP is much more accurate and informative than the "generic" terms of fingering, DK, Worsted, 4 Ply or 8 Ply.

You may have already discovered that 2 balls of "DK Weight" in different fibers or from different manufacturers probably have different yards or meters per ball. One may have 550 yards and another may have 600 yards. If the balls weight the same, the thickness of the yarn itself will be different and they will knit at different gauges on your machine. Comparing DK to DK may not give you the results you want.


Use the Knit it Now "Balls to Cones" Conversion tool to compare yarns by converting their weights and yardage to YPP

example: When you aren't sure if you have enough yarn and start a project anyways, playing "chicken" to the very end.
imageAlt: Knitter assessing remaining yarn for project
imageDescription: Playing Yarn Chicken: Estimating Yarn for Knitting Projects
helpInfo:
We've all done it ... we're not sure if we have enough yarn and get down to the last few yards. Yarn Chicken causes more grey hair than dropped stitches.

Tip 1

Weigh and measure your swatch BEFORE you start knitting. Use the Knit it Now Yarn Estimator to determine if you have enough.


Tip 2

If you only have 1-2 rows left to knit:
A row of stockinette takes about 3 times the width of the knitting.
Measure what you have left against the knitting on the machine.
metaTitle: Yarn Chicken – Knitting Term Explained
metaDescription: 'Yarn Chicken' refers to the risky game knitters play when uncertain if their remaining yarn is sufficient to complete a project, often leading to suspenseful knitting sessions.

example: Specialty ball winder to ply(twist) 2 (or more) strands into 1 strand.
imageAlt: Yarn Twister for creating plying yarns in machine knitting
imageDescription: Yarn Twister used to ply multiple yarns into a consistent, strong strand for machine knitting projects
helpInfo:
Machine knitters, get creative with yarn and color!

Use 2 (or more) thin yarns and make a unique yarn.

1 Run 2 strands of contrasting (or complementary) colors together as you knit.  The yarn will "automatically" create interesting stripes for a graphic design

2Use a yarn twister and the stripes disappear and you get a marled fabric


What's a yarn twister?
A yarn twister is a nifty device that looks similar to a yarn ball winder . It gives you the ability to twist multiple strands of yarn together. It helps to create a smoother, stronger, and more consistent yarn.

  • Twisting will blend colors and change the texture of the resulting yarn strand.
  • You can twist a fancy or textured yarn with a plain yarn.
  • Make thicker yarn and interesting color combinations.
  • Use very fine yarns that may not be suitable to knit singly on the machine
You can find twisters in the used equipment market. Search for Daruma yarn twister

This sample is knitted in full-needle rib (all needles in work) with the beautiful Jaggerspun Superfine Merino 2/18
metaTitle: Yarn Twister: Definition in Machine Knitting
metaDescription: A Yarn Twister is used to ply multiple yarns together, creating a smoother, stronger, and more consistent strand, perfect for blending colors and textures.

example: The term ‘yarn weight’ refers to the thickness of the thread, not the weight of the ball
imageAlt: Various yarn weights displayed for machine knitting
imageDescription: Different Yarn Weights Used in Machine Knitting
helpInfo: The term "yarn weight" refers to the thickness of the yarn strand, not its actual weight or the weight of the ball. Since fibers vary in density, a yard of fluffy aran wool might weigh less than a yarn of 4-ply cotton, even though aran is considered the "heavier" yarn.
metaTitle: Yarn Weight – Machine Knitting Term
metaDescription: Yarn weight refers to the thickness of yarn, crucial in machine knitting for determining gauge, stitch definition, and suitability for various projects.

example: Device for creating balls (or cakes) of yarn for easier machine knitting.
imageAlt: Yarn winder preparing yarn for machine knitting
imageDescription: Yarn Winder in Use for Machine Knitting Preparation
helpInfo:
As machine knitters, it's important that the yarn is "put up" so it can easily pass through the yarn tensioner for knitting.

Yarn that is put up in skeins and hanks cannot be used for machine knitting unless it is wound on a cone or in balls (or cakes).

Many machine knitters will also re-wind yarn into balls and check for knots before using it for machine knitting.

We recommend the Knit Picks Ball Winder for its ease of use and efficiency. Affiliate link
metaTitle: Yarn Winder – Essential Machine Knitting Tool
metaDescription: A yarn winder is a device used in machine knitting to transform skeins or hanks of yarn into neat, manageable cakes or balls, ensuring consistent tension and smooth knitting.

example: Controlled holes used to make lace, small buttonholes and specialized stitch techniques. [yo] is a hand knitting term
imageAlt: yo (yarn over) technique for creating eyelets in machine knitting
imageDescription: yo (yarn over) technique used in machine knitting to create eyelets for lace and buttonholes
helpInfo:
Similar to a [k2tog, yo] in hand knitting, transferring a single stitch to its neighboring needle will create a hole. Leaving the emptied needle in working position completes the eyelet.

Eyelets can be hand transferred or created with a lace carriage (standard gauge machines only)

Eyelets have many uses including lace, decorative stitches, buttonholes and more.

example: Bind off needles 1-10 left of Zero
imageAlt: Animated GIF showing a knitting machine needlebed number strip shifting, demonstrating why knitters should mark the true zero point.
imageDescription: Needlebed zero point demonstration
helpInfo:
The “zero needle” is not a needle. It's the reference point at the very center of your knitting machine’s needle bed. It’s essential for aligning patterns, centering your work, and coordinating with a ribber.

It's often referred to in knitting instruction as "10-1 left" of Zero or "1-10 right of zero"

Zero on the needlebed
metaTitle: Zero Needle in Machine Knitting | Center Reference Point
metaDescription: The zero needle is the center reference point on a knitting machine’s needle bed. Learn why marking true zero is essential for aligning patterns, centering projects, and using a ribber

example: The foundation row for all ribbing. The yarn travels back and forth between the main bed and ribber needles.
imageAlt: Zig Zag Cast On technique for ribbing in machine knitting
imageDescription: Zig Zag Cast On technique for ribbing using ribber and main bed needles in machine knitting
helpInfo:
Basic Ribber cast on:

  • Swing "P"
  • Needles in desired needle arrangement
  • Knit a zig zag row (tension 0 on both beds)
  • Insert Ribber Cast On Comb
  • Knit selvage (3 rows Tubular )
  • Set for plain knitting (or pattern or choice)
  • Continue knitting
metaTitle: Zig Zag Cast On (Ribber): Definition in Machine Knitting
metaDescription: The Zig Zag Cast On for ribbing uses the ribber to create a foundation row with yarn traveling between the main bed and ribber needles, perfect for ribbed edges.
